details.name: Acetone
details.description: A chemical with an abnormal fruity odor
details.findings: Acetone concentration in breath changes during activities such as exercising or fasting.
details.notes: Not recommended as a biomarker due to changing concentrations

details.name: 4-Heptanone
details.description: A VOC with unclear origins
details.findings: The origin of 4-heptanone is unclear, limiting its use as a biomarker.
details.notes: Not recommended as a biomarker due to unclear origins

details.name: SIFT-MS
details.description: Selected Ion Flow Tube-Mass Spectrometry
details.findings: SIFT-MS can analyze VOCs in patients' exhaled breath to predict cancers.
details.notes: Used with XGBoost model for accurate prediction

details.name: Microbiome
details.description: A collection of microorganisms living in a particular habitat
details.findings: The article discusses the use of explainable AI to identify microbiome-based biomarkers for colorectal cancer.
details.notes: Important for understanding the relationship between microbiome and disease

details.name: SH2B3
details.description: A protein that plays a role in immune function and has been linked to various diseases
details.findings: The article mentions SH2B3 as a potential biomarker for colorectal cancer.
details.notes: Requires further research to understand its role in disease diagnosis

details.name: Acetone
details.description: A secondary product of lipid peroxidation and a good predictor for ketosis
details.findings: Acetone levels were found to be different in the breath of CRC patients compared to controls
details.notes: Related to ketones family and formed under metabolic conditions associated with high oxidation rate of fatty acids

knowledge.subject: Acetone
knowledge.object: metabolic conditions associated with high oxidation rate of fatty acids

details.name: Alkenes
details.description: Hydrocarbons that can be found in human breath
details.findings: Alkenes were identified as one of the VOCs differentially present in the breath of CRC patients
details.notes: Originates from oxidative stress and is excreted in the breath due to low solubility in blood

details.name: Alcohols
details.description: Compounds that can be derived from food, alcohol beverages, and metabolism of hydrocarbons
details.findings: Alcohols were found to be present in the breath of CRC patients, possibly related to metabolic changes
details.notes: Mostly originate from food and alcohol beverages, and are also derived from hydrocarbon metabolism by cytochrome p450 enzymes

details.name: Esters
details.description: Compounds that can be found in natural sources such as fats and fatty oils, waxes, and fruit ethers
details.findings: Esters were identified as one of the VOCs differentially present in the breath of CRC patients
details.notes: Can be found in large amounts in natural sources, but their role in CRC is not fully understood

details.name: 4-Methyl-1-pentene
details.description: Not explicitly described in the article, but mentioned as one of the identified VOCs
details.findings: This compound was found to be differentially present in the breath of CRC patients compared to controls
details.notes: No additional information is provided about this compound in the article

details.name: T-antigen
details.description: a cancer-associated glycan
details.findings: Stools from more aggressive lesions may exhibit abnormal immature T-antigen signatures not seen in healthy tissues.
details.notes: potential biomarker for non-invasive cancer diagnostics

details.name: core 1/T-antigen
details.description: a modification of serine and threonine with Hex(1)HexNAc(1)
details.findings: Modification of serine and threonine with core 1/T-antigen was allowed in the analysis.
details.notes: relevant for identifying cancer-associated glycoproteins

details.name: stool glycoproteome
details.description: the set of glycoproteins found in stool samples
details.findings: The stool glycoproteome was characterized and several molecular targets were identified.
details.notes: potential source of biomarkers for non-invasive cancer diagnostics

llama3.3:70b-instruct-q8_0/PPEkf.prompt_template:
[BEGIN ARTICLE]:<content></content>
[END ARTICLE]

[INSTRUCTIONS]
Generate list of biomarkers that are topic of the article and for each such biomarker extract name, description, type, findings explicitly mentioned in the article, and list of knowledge.
The list of knowledge that are from finding and that can be expressed in terms: 'subject' which is the biomarker, 'predicate' which is some verb optionally with some adverb and 'object'.
Return the response in strict JSON format with the following structure:

[
  { "name": "biomarker name","type":"biomarker type","description":"biomarker description","findings":"brief findings about biomarker in article as one sentence","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker", "knowledge":[{'subject':'repeated biomarker name','predicate':'some predicate from findings of biomarker','object':'object that relates via predicate to the biomarker' }],
  { "name": "biomarker2 name","type":"biomarker2 type","description":"biomarker2 description","findings":"brief findings about biomarker2 in article as one sentence","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker2", "knowledge":[{'subject':'repeated biomarker2 name','predicate':'some predicate from findings of  biomarker2','object':'object that relates via predicate to the biomarker2' }] }
] 

Ensure there is no additional explanation, only return valid JSON.
